Can anybody here give me some titles of books that are about the current state of the US economy and the events that have lead up to it?
 Most of the information I get right now are from websites, but most of them are only a couple of pages and I'm getting tired of googling 20+ websites to get a good read.
 
 If at all possible I'd also like a few titles which make comparisons between the US and European economies since IMO Europe is now heading (albeit very slowly) towards the way the US economy is right now (High labour costs, loss of manufacturing jobs, high social security costs, aging working population. Though thankfully the ECB doesn't hold nearly as much power as the Fed, nor is our foreign debt as high as that of the US).

I emailed someone I know and this was recommended:
 
 The Boom and The Bubble: The US in the World Economy
 Robert Brenner 
 
 I haven't read it, but the referrer says its a good one. I took a look at it on Amazon, reviews here:
 
 http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/customer-reviews/1859844839/ref=dp_nav_0/102-9957563-1033758?%5Fencoding=UTF8&n=283155&s=books. 
 
 From the reviews he seems more reporter than economist, valuable in that 500 pure economists will have 500 different opinions and a kajillion models focused on pet theories and whatever's paying the bills. With your market experience, you should have no problem with this one.

I read some reviews and it looks very promising. I ordered it and hopefully it will be here before the weekend.
 
 Thank you very much. :)
i'd just read the financial times, the economists, and the wall street journal

i'd just read the financial times, the economists, and the wall street journal

 
 I second this list. If it isn't there, it isn't worth printing.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Books about the US economy
